raw_comment:
With both the amount of wealth and legacy has great effects on the % of admission. Overall if you have higher of both then its a good thing but, if you have neither that's also good. There is however no inbetween.

Where did the stigma come from to have money and a legacy? Or neither. Is it really about BOTH or just the money. Is it a way for the top % to write money off on their taxes?

As an up and coming college applicant, it's valuable to see how I place myself in these categories. Thinking about how myself as a student many stack up against other applicants of different demographics    

All or nothing, The extremes that colleges are looking for.
ace_sentences: Legacy status affects the admission rate.
If a person has high wealth and has legacy status then the admission rate is high.
If a person has neither wealth nor legacy status then the admission rate is high.
There is no middle case between these two cases.
There is a stigma about having money and having legacy status.
There is a stigma about having neither money nor legacy status.
I ask where this stigma came from.
I ask whether admission is about both wealth and legacy status.
I ask whether admission is only about wealth.
I ask whether rich people use donations to reduce taxes.
I am an up-and-coming college applicant.
It is valuable for me to see my category.
I think about how I compare with other applicants.
Colleges look for an all-or-nothing case.
